Immobilized enzymes have encountered two main challenges: Reduced enzyme activity compared to free enzymes and exhausted immobilized enzymes due to reusability. Herein, we suggested a promising activity enhancement strategy to overcome these challenges. The emission from upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) under near-infrared (NIR) excitation can increase the activity of PEG-l-ASNase due to Förster Resonance Energy Transfer. For this purpose, UCNPs were initially synthesized using the hydrothermal method. Subsequently, these UCNPs were functionalized with a polycationic polymer, branched polyethyleneimine (PEI), and the immobilization of PEG-l-ASNase was achieved through adsorption. We preliminarily explored the parameters such as enzyme concentration, incubation time, pH, temperature, reusability, storage stability, and kinetic study, etc. Further, the in vitro biocompatibility, hemolytic behavior, and anticancer activity of the produced UCNPs were also analyzed as crucial parameters. The results showed the pH durance, thermal and storage stability of the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were enhanced. The immobilized PEG-l-ASNases maintained their activity to ≥55 % after 20 cycles. Enzyme immobilization led to a decrease in Km and Vmax compared to PEG-l-ASNase. In vitro assays revealed that immobilized enzyme further reduced the proliferation of human leukemia cell line (HL-60) upon NIR irradiation exposure but did not cause toxicity. This research may provide a new strategy to promote the catalytic activity of l-ASNase and demonstrates its potential application on human leukemia cells. Finally, these outcomes are valuable for the use of NIR induction in enzymatic reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lanthanide-doped nanoparticles Light-induced supports Near- infrared irradiation Förster resonance energy transfer Triggered activity Thermostability Reusability Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Enzymes have important advantages in various industrial applications and these advantages of enzymes has made them a popular subject for scientific studies and commercial utilities [1–6]. However, their catalytic performance is limited by their poor recovery and low stability [7,8]. To overcome these limitations, there is tremendous interest in enhancing enzyme activity, efficiency, stability, and reusability. Generally, the methods of promoting enzymatic reactions are focused on three aspects: enzyme modification, substrate pretreatment, and enhancement of enzyme-substrate combination [9]. These improvements can be attained via chemical, physical and genetic methods or a combination of these approaches [10,11]. Among these methods, the use of external stimuli to improve the interactions between enzyme and substrate is one of the most important techniques. To date, various external stimuli have been explored, including ultrasound [12,13], magnetic field [14–16], and pulsed electric field [17,18] for enhancement of enzyme activity. Each approach offers advantages and limitations for enzyme immobilization. However, to date, previous investigations of the effects of near infrared (NIR) have mainly focused on photoimmunotherapy [19,20] and drug delivery [21,22], whereas little work has been performed regarding its effect on enzymatic reactions. Moreover, the mechanism of the enzymatic reactions between NIR-induced enzyme and substrat are unclear. Thus, it is necessary and important to reveal the effects of NIR on enzymatic reactions and the mechanisms in the enzymatic reactions between NIR-induced enzymes and substrat solutions. The aim of this work was to investigate the enzymatic activity of l-asparaginase (L-ASNase) in the presence of a NIR and to explore the mechanisms by which the NIR influences enzyme activity. We anticipate that this novel approach will provide theoretical guidance and different perspectives for the practical applications of enzymes. l-ASNase (E.C.3.5.1.1) was chosen as the model enzyme because it has been widely used as a chemotherapeutic drug in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and other malignant diseases including Hodgkin's disease, acute myelocytic leukemia, acute myelomonocytic leukemia, chronic lymphocytic leukemia [23]. However, there are factors that limit its chemotherapeutic efficacy. Although it has been produced from a variety of sources including bacteria, yeast, fungi, plant fungi, plants and actinomycetes [24], commercial l-ASNase has been obtained from Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Erwinia chrysanthemi (E. chrysanthemi). Because l-ASNase is a bacterial enzyme of high of bacterial origin and high molecular weight, it is recognized by the body's immune system [23,25,26]. As a result, the half-life of l-ASNase decreases. Immobilization strategy is a technical process in which enzymes are fixed to or within solid supports, creating a stable and reusable enzyme system [27]. Three different types of l-ASNase are currently available for use in the treatment of ALL. Native E. colil-ASNase and pegylated (PEG)-l-ASNase are derived from E. coli bacteria. In addition, l-ASNase E. chrysanthemi is derived from E. chrysanthemi [28]. PEG-l-ASNase has a longer half-life and limited side effects than its free form. PEG-l-ASNase has a plasma half-life of 5–8 days, native E. coli ASNase between 8 and 30 h, and Erwinia ASNase of 4–22 h [29]. Even though the immobilization method offers significant advantages, it is clear that there is still a need for technologies that can be applied to biological systems, which will further improve the application, triggering the activities of these enzyme drugs and preserving their half-life in the blood. This pilot study highlights the potential of UCNPs by NIR-induced to promote PEG-l-ASNase in biomedical applications. Rare earth upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) are a unique class of lanthanide-doped optical nanocrystals. They have the characteristic of anti-Stokes luminescence, which indicates their ability to emit short wavelength, high frequency light when excited with longer wavelength, lower frequency light [30]. More simply, when exposed to near-infrared (NIR) radiation, UCNPs exhibit the ability to emit light across a spectrum ranging from ultraviolet (UV) to NIR bands [31]. Moreover, UCNPs have attractive advantages such as outstanding photostability and low toxicity as well as increased light penetration depth in biological tissues [32]. Therefore, they find widespread utility in various biological applications, prominently in imaging [33], therapeutics [34], and, notably, drug delivery systems [35]. Several lanthanide ions (Yb3+, Tm3+, Er3+, Ho3+, and Tb3+) have been found to be activators for the photon upconversion process [36]. Within the structure of UCNPs, there exists both an absorber and a luminescent ion. Sensitizers, such as Yb3+ and Nd3+, are commonly employed to augment the NIR absorption capability of UCNPs. In contrast, lanthanide ions like Er3+, Tm3+, and Ho3+ function as activators, facilitating the attainment of the desired energy level or transfer [37]. UCNPs have the ability to convert low-energy photons from the NIR region of light into high-energy photons of the UV–Vis region of light. High-energy UV–Vis photons can be used to activate the catalytic activity of enzymes through the Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) [31]. In our recent study, isocyanate-modified NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+UCNPs were synthesized and PEG-l-ASNase enzyme was immobilized by covalent binding method. In in vitro and in vivo experiments, the activity of the PEG-l-ASNase was increased approximately 5 and 2 times, respectively, under NIR exposure [37]. Unlike our previous study, in the present investigation, the improvements in the activity of the PEG-l-ASNase immobilized to UCNPs modified by the adsorption method were monitored under NIR excitation. A sequential experimental method was monitored to assess the effects of enzyme concentration, NIR-excitation intensity, distance of induction, and exposure time on the enzyme activity. The present study demonstrates and reports a new material and technique for immobilizing PEG-l-ASNase and inducing its activity on pre-designed amino-enriched UCNP support. Polyethylenimine (PEI) was chosen as a polyamine because it is a linear or branched, amino-enriched polymer [38]. Thus, it can introduce some amino groups into the UCNP support to facilitate higher immobilization of the enzyme. The immobilization conditions (immobilization time and enzyme concentration) of PEG-l-ASNase were optimized. Thorough physicochemical, morphological, and catalytic characteristics of the produced UCNPs and UCNPs@PEG-l-ASNase were performed in order to select the most suitable support for NIR irradiation. Afterward, the optimum pH, optimum temperature, activation energy, pH stability, thermal stability, storage stability, reusability, and kinetic parameters of immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were analyzed in comparison with that of PEG-l-ASNase. Besides, the adsorption behaviors of UCNPs@PEG-l-ASNase, including and isotherm and kinetic models were also discussed. Additionally, the effects of metallic ions, organic solvents, and trypsin digestion on the activity of enzyme samples were investigated. In vitro toxicity assessments for both UCNPs and UCNPs@PEG-l-ASNase were conducted using the mouse fibroblast cell line (L-929). Most importantly, in vitro antitumor efficacy studies were carried out for NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase with optimized properties, targeting an acute leukemic cell line (HL-60) under NIR irradiation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on amino-enriched UCNP support functionalized with PEI for PEG-l-ASNase immobilization by means of adsorption. On the other hand, the induction of PEG-l-ASNase activity by NIR irradiation was another unique and innovative aspect of this study. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials Ytterbium (III) chloride hexahydrate (YbCl3·6H2O), erbium (III) chloride hexahydrate (ErCl3·6H2O), and neodymium (III) chloride hexahydrate (NdCl3·6H2O) were purchased from FluoroChem (Hadfield, UK). Yttrium (III) chloride hexahydrate (YCl3·6H2O) was obtained from Chempure. Ammonium fluoride (NH4F) and PEI (branched MW: 25.000 g/mol) were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). PEG-l-ASNase, l-asparagine, and trichloroacetic acid (TCA) were provided by Sigma-Aldrich (St Louis, MO, USA). Unless otherwise stated, all other chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification. Immediately before use, the enzyme and substrate solutions were freshly prepared. Distilled water was used throughout the study. 2.2 Synthesis of UCNPs To synthesize NaYF4: Yb3+, Er3+, firstly, the reaction mixtures were prepared with YCl3·6H2O (1.6 mmol), YbCl3·6H2O (0.36 mmol), ErCl3·6H2O (0.04 mmol), and NaCl (2 mmol), and this mixture was added to the Teflon vessel, which is part of the hydrothermal synthesis system. Thereafter, NH4F (10 mmol) was dissolved in 60 mL of anhydrous ethanol and added to the reaction mixture. The Teflon vessel was placed in the hydrothermal unit in a steel container and heated at 200 °C for 4 h. After the reaction was completed, the UCNPs were cooled down to room temperature, and the white solid formed was centrifuged at 10.000 rpm for 15 min. The white precipitates were washed 3 times with a mixture of ethanol: water (1:1, v/v), filtered and dried overnight at 40 °C in a vacuum oven. To synthesize NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+UCNPs, NdCl3·6H2O as well as other lanthanide salts was added to the reaction medium and the procedure detailed above was applied. 2.3 PEI modification The PEG-l-ASNase is negatively charged in pH 7.0 to 7.4 [39]. Therefore, UCNPs were modified with positive surface charge PEI (branched MW: 25,000 g/mol) for PEG-l-ASNase to interact electrostatically with UCNPs. In the experimental procedure, the amount of PEI to be used over the yield of naked UCNP synthesis was determined. For this purpose, PEI solution (UCNP g/30 mL water) was added to the synthesis medium of UCNPs. Then, PEI-modified UCNPs were taken from the mixture by centrifugation at 10.000 rpm for 15 min. The final product was washed 3 times with a mixture of ethanol: water (1:1, v/v) to remove excess PEI, filtered, and dried overnight at 40 °C in a vacuum oven. In order to evaluate the effect of PEI coating ratio on surface charge and enzyme immobilization efficiency, UCNP surfaces were coated with PEI solution with three different concentrations (m(PEI)/m(totally solid mass): 2 %, 5 %, and 7 %). 2.4 Immobilization of PEG-l-ASNase Scheme 1 indicates a schematic presentation of the synthesis of UCNPs@PEG-l-ASNase and triggering of enzyme activity by NIR. To determine the optimum enzyme amount for physical immobilization, 25 mg of UCNPs were incubated with different amounts (5, 10, 25, 50, 75, and 100 U) of PEG-l-ASNase at +4 °C for different incubation times (0.5–12 h). Subsequently, the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were collected by centrifugation separation, washed several times with Tris–HCl buffer to remove the unimmobilized PEG-l-ASNase, and stored at 4 °C until further use. The immobilization yield (IY) was determined by measuring the protein concentration of the enzyme solution before and after immobilization via the Bradford method [40]. BSA was used as a standard protein. The following formula (Eq. (1)) to calculate immobilization yield (IY) was used: (1) I Y ( % ) = [ ( C 1 − C 2 ) / C 1 ] x 100 where C1 and C2 were the concentrations of protein used for immobilization and present in the supernatant after immobilization, respectively. Also, the activity efficiency (AE) was calculated using Eq. (2). (2) A E ( % ) = ( A c t . o f i m m o b i l i z e d P E G L − A S N a s e / A c t . o f P E G − L − A S N a s e ) x 100 2.5 Enzyme activity assay The PEG-l-ASNase enzyme activity was measured by the Nesslerization technique [41]. This technique is based on the approach of colorimetric measurement of the ammonia formed by hydrolysis of l-asparagine by l-ASNase. Briefly, PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were placed in a tube and a solution of a freshly prepared substrate (10 mM, 1 mL) with Tris–HCl (50 mM, pH 8.6) buffer was added. The reaction solution was incubated for 15 min and the enzymatic reaction was then terminated by adding TCA solution (1.5 M, 100 µL). Then, 100 µL of the solution was added to the 96 well plates and reacted with Nessler reagent (100 mL), and a yellow-orange color was observed. The absorbance of the obtained color was measured spectrophotometrically at 480 nm with a microplate reader device after 10 min of incubation at room temperature. One unit of enzyme activity (IU) is defined as the amount of enzyme that releases 1 µmol of ammonia per minute under optimum conditions. All experiments were performed using three parallel samples and the data obtained were graphically presented as mean ± SD (standard deviation). 2.6 Adsorption isotherms and kinetic Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models were estimated by Eq. (3) [42] and Eq. (4) [43], respectively: (3) qe = qmaxKLCe 1 + KLCe (4) lnqe = lnKF + 1 n lnCe Where qe is the amount of PEG-l-ASNase enzyme adsorbed on NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI (µg/mg). qm is the Langmuir maximum adsorption capacity at equilibrium to form complete monolayer (µg/mg) and KL is the Langmuir equilibrium constant (mL/mg) that corresponds to sorption bonding energy. Ce is the equilibrium concentration of PEG-l-ASNase enzyme (mg/mL). KF (mL/mg) and 1/n are empirical parameters as Freundlich constants reported as function of intensity and energy distribution on adsorbent site [44]. Moreover, the intraparticle diffusion model was expressed by the following Eq. (5) [45]: (5) qt = kintrat 0 . 5 + C Where kintra = intraparticle diffusion rate constant (µg/mg·min0.5) and C is the intercept [44]. 2.7 Biochemical characterization To determine the optimum temperature value of the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases, the enzyme activities were measured from 20 to 70 ⁰C, respectively, and the relative activities were compared. The highest activity was considered as 100 % and the results were given as relative activity. To determine the optimum pH value of the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases, the enzyme activities were measured by using substrate solutions prepared with different pH buffers, and the relative activities were compared. The buffers are as follows; citrate buffer (50 mM, pH 4.0, 5.0, and 6.0), phosphate buffer (50 mM, 7.0, 7.5, and 8.0), and Tris–HCl (50 mM, pH 8.5, 9.0, and 10.0). The highest activity was considered as 100 % and the results were given as relative activity. To investigate the reusability of the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases, the activity was measured consecutively under optimum conditions. After each cycle, the sample was separated from the reaction system by centrifugation and then washed with buffer. After that, a fresh substrate solution was added to the sample, and the residual activity was measured according to the standard enzyme procedure. This process was repeated twenty times. The first enzyme activity was assumed to be 100 % and subsequent activities were calculated relatively. For the measurement of thermal resistance, and pH stability, the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were incubated at 50 ⁰C, and pH 4 and 9, respectively, for 6 h. The activities were measured and the initial activities were assumed to be 100 % in all cases. For storage stability, the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were stored at 4 ⁰C and room temperature for 28 days, and their activities were measured every 7 days. The initial activity value was assumed to be 100 % and the results were given as relative activity. To explore the impact of metal ions and organic solvents on the activities of both PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases, pre-incubation was carried out in the presence of 10 mM metal ions or 5 % (v/v) organic solvent for a specified duration. Following a 24-h incubation period, the activity of each condition was assessed using the standard assay, and the results were expressed relative to the control (lacking any metal ions and organic solvent), which served as the baseline set at 100 %. 2.8 Kinetic parameters and activation energy The kinetic parameters (Km and Vmax) of the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were evaluated by measuring activity in different concentrations of l-asparagine under standard assay conditions. The Km and Vmax values were calculated using Lineweaver and Burk's plot, which is derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation [46]. Additionally, the activation energy (Ea) was also determined using the Arrhenius equation [41]. 2.9 Stability test in serum and trypsin digestion Stability tests of the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases in serum were determined as previously described [47]. The PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were incubated for one week at 37 °C with rat blood serum samples. After one week of incubation, the activity of reactive plasma containing PEG-l-ASNase, and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases was measured using the standard enzyme procedure at 1, 3, and 7 days. A major problem of bacterial enzymes used as pharmaceuticals is their low stability against proteases. Therefore, to test the resistance against trypsin, the PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were added to trypsin solution (1.0 mg mL−1) and the final mixture was incubated from 0 to 2 h. Afterward, their residual activities were measured. 2.10 Effect of metallic ions and organic solvents on enzyme activities The impact of various metallic ions (Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, and Cr3+) at a concentration of 10 mM on both PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases was assessed through a 24-h incubation period. Furthermore, the influence of organic solvents (ethanol, tetrahydrofuran (THF), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dichloromethane (DCM), 2-propanol, and hexane) at a concentration of 5 % (v/v) on PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases was investigated over a 24-h incubation period. The enzyme activity, considered as 100 % in the absence of any metallic ion and organic solvent under optimal conditions (control group), served as the baseline. Subsequently, the activity in the presence of each metal ion and organic solvent was compared with the control group, and the outcomes were expressed as a percentage of relative activity [48]. 2.11 Laser characterization experiments The parameters such as laser power, laser distance, and laser exposure time were optimized (one by one) until the maximum relative activity was achieved. Firstly, the laser power was scanned between the range (0–5000 mW) for both 980 nm and 808 nm of the diode laser. The laser was applied at a distance ranging from 1.0 to 5.0 cm between the sample and the laser source. Laser exposure time is another parameter for optimizing laser experiments. After determining the optimum laser power and distance, the laser exposure time was changed from 0 to 120 min. 2.12 Cell viability Cell viability was determined by using the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)−2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay method [49,50]. l-929 mouse fibroblast cells were grown in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) containing 10 % fetal bovine serum (FBS), 1 % penicillin/streptomycin and incubated at 37 °C with 5 % CO2. The cells were seeded into 96-well plates with 104 cells per well to grow for 24 h. After 24 h, the different concentrations (12.5, 25, 50, 100, and 200 μg mL−1) of UCNPs and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases solutions prepared with DMEM were applied to the wells and they were incubated at 37 °C under 5 % CO2 for 24, 48, and 72 h. After 24, 48, and 72 h incubation, the medium was removed and replaced with 90 µL of fresh DMEM. Then, 10 µL of MTT (5 mg mL−1 in PBS solution) was added to each well. After 4 h incubation, the MTT solution was removed and the cells were treated with 100 μL dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The absorbance of the resulting color was measured with a microreader reader at 540 nm. The viability of cells without samples was considered 100 %. 2.13 Hemolysis assay The hemolysis assay was carried out as described by Hu et al. [51] with minor modifications. Briefly, whole blood from Wistar rats was isolated by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 15 min to obtain erythrocytes. 0.5 mL of the diluted erythrocyte solution with PBS (2 %, v/v) was added to 0.5 mL of PBS containing different concentrations of immobilized PEG-l-ASNases (final concentration of 12.5, 25, 50, 100, and 200 μg mL−1). Deionized water and PBS were used as positive and negative controls, respectively. All samples were incubated for 3 h at 37 °C, followed by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 5 min to remove intact erythrocytes. Subsequently, the optical density (OD) values of the supernatants at 540 nm were measured using a microplate reader. The experiments were performed in triplicate. The hemolysis rate (HR) was calculated according to the following Eq. (6): (6) HR ( % ) = ODs − ODn . c ODp . c − ODn . c x 100 where OD s , OD p.c , and OD n.c represent the OD values of the sample, positive control, and negative control, respectively. 2.14 Determination of inhibition on cancer cells The MTT assay was used to measure the in vitro antitumor efficacy of NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, as previously mentioned [52]. Promyelocytic leukemia cell lines (HL-60) were employed for cell culture, and they were kept in an incubator with 5 % CO2 at 37 °C and supplemented with 10 % FBS and 1 % penicillin/streptomycin. The cells were kept in this medium until they achieved 80–90 % confluence. 25 × 104 HL-60 cells were seeded in 2 mL centrifuge tubes, and the tubes were spun for 5 min at 2000 rpm. Following that, the pellet and supernatant were carefully separated, and 1 mg/mL of sample suspension was added to the pellets. As a control, the experiment also included cells that were not exposed to NIR radiation or samples. Twice every six hours, groups containing NIR were exposed to a 150 mW 808 nm laser for 30 min. After NIR irradiation, the cells were seeded into 96-well plates, which were then incubated for 24 h at 37 °C with a 5 % CO2 flow. Following a 24-hour incubation period, the studies were conducted as previously mentioned. There are n = 8 repetitions in each group. The information was presented as a mean percentage of inhibition of HL-60 cell proliferation. The mean ± SD of eight measurements is the result. 2.15 Instruments FTIR measurements were acquired on a Perkin Elmer, spectrum two model FTIR spectrometer. The spectra were recorded in a wavenumber range between 4000 and 400 cm−1. The phases of the UCNPs were determined by dust X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku Ultima-IV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained with a Jeol 2100F microscope using an accelerating voltage at 200 kV. The samples were prepared by placing a droplet of UCNPs (1 mg/mL) in water: methanol (1:1) onto a 3 mm copper grid and dried under air at room temperature. The zeta potentials of the UCNPs were determined by ZetaSizer (Anton Paar, Litesizer 500). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of the UCNPs was performed using a Perkin Elmer, STA 8000 model. TGA experiments were performed over a temperature range of 30–800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere, switching to synthetic air at 800 °C (20 mL/min), and using a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The photophysical characterizations of the UCNPs were determined by a fluorescence spectrometer (Ocean Optics USB2000) using an external 980 nm and 808 nm continuous laser irradiation. A microplate reader (BioTek Instruments, USA) was used for measuring absorbance and the recorded absorbance was converted to enzyme activity by using a standard curve. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization In this study, we hypothesized that the energy transfer via the FRET mechanism in UCNP that emit in the visible region when excited under NIR light with wavelengths of 980 nm and 808 nm can increase the activity of the PEG-l-ASNase enzyme that we immobilized on the UCNP surface. The aim was to enable PEG-l-ASNase to connect through physical interactions. Since the operating pH in biological systems is 7.4 and the charge of PEG-l-ASNase is negative at this pH, the synthesized UCNPs surfaces must be positively charged. For this purpose, low amounts of PEI polymer, which is non-toxic, biocompatible, has a large number of amine end groups and has a branched structure, which is frequently used in biomaterial technologies, was used to coat UCNP surfaces. In the experimental study, two approaches were used to coat UCNP surfaces: during and after synthesis. Coating the nanoparticle surfaces dispersed in the solvent with PEI after synthesis requires additional processing steps, it was observed that homogeneous coatings could not be obtained on the particle surfaces and the coating rates could not be controlled. Coating the particle surfaces with in situ PEI was preferred because it both prevents the disadvantages mentioned above and helps control particle growth. This article includes experimental results of pure and enzyme-loaded UCNPs surface coated with PEI in situ. Three different PEI mass ratios were studied in situ PEI coating of UCNP surfaces and the amount of PEI was worked out to be w(PEI)/w (amount of solid in a mixture) = 2, 5, and 7. Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+UCNPs coated in three different mass ratios. All peaks marked in the spectrum show the planes of the β-NaYF4 hexagonal crystal phase (JCPDS No. 16–0334), which is compatible with the literature. While no change in the existing hexagonal crystal structure planes was observed in the PEI coatings at 2 % and 5 % rates, a signal regarding the cubic structure was observed in the XRD pattern of the 7 % PEI-coated UCNPs. It is known that the β-hexagonal crystal structure is reached at higher temperature-pressure values than the cubic structure. Therefore, first cubic structure is formed and then the transformation into a hexagonal structure occurs. When the amount of PEI increased from 5 % to 7 %, the conversion did not occur completely and therefore the signal of the cubic crystal structure appeared in the XRD pattern. In this case, PEI requires a crystal phase transition. NaYF4, which has a hexagonal crystal structure (β-phase), is preferred because its upconverting (UC) process yield is much higher than that of a cubic crystal structure (α-phase) [53]. Fig. 1B shows the FTIR spectra in the range of nanoparticles synthesized and whose surface was coated with PEI in situ. There is a broad band seen in the 3050–3400 cm−1 range in the spectrum, which includes signals in the 500–4000 cm−1 range the band belongs to the primary amine stretching vibrations originating from PEI and the vibrations of hydroxyl groups existing on the UCNPs surface. Immediately next to it, peaks belonging to aliphatic CH stretches are seen in the wavelength range of 2700–2900 cm−1. In the range of 1600 cm−1 and 900–700 cm−1, peaks corresponding to NH in-plane bending vibrations are observed. The characteristic CN bond stretching was in the range of 1120–1050 cm−1. The signal observed at 470 cm−1 is the stretching vibrations of the PEI-Ln3+ bond. As the amount of PEI coating increased, the signal intensities of the relevant functional groups also increased. As is well known, thermogravimetric analysis is used to determine the behavior of materials against temperature. With this analysis, the thermal resistance, thermal decomposition stages, and phase transition temperatures of the materials can be determined. In this study, it was used to determine the amount of PEI coated on the surfaces of inorganic oxide UCNPs. In the analyzes carried out in the presence of N2(g) in the temperature range of 30–800 °C, the amount of organic PEI was approximately determined over the thermal decomposition temperature zones. As can be seen in Fig. 1C, there are significant differences between the theoretical values used in the in situ coating of the surfaces of UCNPs and the results obtained from thermograms. Depending on the coating rates on the particle surfaces, the decomposition starting and ending temperatures of organic groups changed. In the study, a thin PEI coating was targeted for the efficient operation of the FRET mechanism under NIR excitation on surface-coated and enzyme-loaded UCNPs. From the TG curves, it was seen that the thinnest coating was theoretically achieved with 5 % PEI coatings by mass. As it is known, one of the main factors that ensures the stable distribution of particles in the environment in which they will be used is particle size and the other is zeta potential. For a stable dispersion, the zeta potential must be >±30 mV [54]. The zeta potentials of dispersions in water of UCNP samples coated with PEI at 2 %, 5 %, and 7 % by mass were measured as 59.60 ± 3.42 mV, 59.07 ± 0.42, and 54.06 ± 0.61 mV, respectively. All three particles have a high surface charge due to the terminal amine groups in the PEI structure. The fact that the particle surface loads are quite high indicates that the desired conditions for enzyme binding as well as stability are met. Although the zeta potentials of 2 % and 5 % PEI-coated particles are at the same values, there are significant differences in the standard deviations. According to the actual PEI coating rates revealed by TG results, it was observed that as the amount of PEI coating increased (2 %PEI/UCNP>7 %PEI/UCNP>5 %PEI/UCNP), the standard deviation also increased. This also indicates the coating homogeneity on the particle surface. The results show that more homogeneous surfaces can be obtained with thin coatings. From the TEM image given in Fig. 2 , it can be seen that the particles are rod-shaped. Theoretically, the amount of coating on the surface (approximately 12.5 nm) is significantly higher in mass 2 % PEI coatings compared to others, as the amount of PEI added to the solvent environment for coating during synthesis increases, it is observed that the particle shapes begin to deteriorate due to the increase in solution viscosity. In addition, it was observed from the TEM photographs of the particles synthesized in the theoretically highest amount of PEI that structures with spherical geometry were formed in some regions where the uniform geometry was disrupted. As the signal is seen in the XRD patterns, these are thought to be particles with a cubic crystal structure. The size of the UCNP-enzyme interface region is an important parameter in transporting the visible region emission generated as a result of NIR active laser excitation in UCNPs to the enzyme to be immobilized on the particle surface. It is aimed that the PEI coating on the particle surfaces not only does not prevent the formation of the desired UCNP crystal structure, but also be in the minimum amount that will ensure physical adsorption and stable UCNP-enzyme dispersions in the aqueous environment. From the analyzes detailed above, the hexagonal crystal structure in three different PEI coatings was determined, it has been observed that 5 % PEI-UCNPs provide these features such as homogeneous surface coating and high surface charge. After this stage, a 5 % PEI coating ratio by mass was used in all studies conducted for particles sensitive to both 980 nm and 808 nm laser excitation. Green light emission in the high-energy 500–600 nm wavelength range is produced through the anti-stokes emission process under low-energy 980 nm laser excitation by co-doping Yb3+ as the absorber ion and Er3+ as the activator ion into the NaYF4 main matrix. The intensity of green emission varies depending on the concentration of Er3+ doped into the main matrix [55]. Under 980 nm laser excitation, the absorption bands of Yb3+ overlap with the absorption of water molecules in the Yb3+ sensitizer ion UC process. This overlap limits NIR light absorption and visible light conversion production. Especially in biological applications, long irradiation at 980 nm can be strongly absorbed by water molecules in biological samples and trigger the overheating effect, triggering cell death and tissue damage. The best way to minimize this overheating effect is to shift the excitation wavelength from 980 nm to 808 nm by introducing Nd3+ ions into the Yb3+/Er3+ bonded UC system due to the low absorption coefficient of water at 808 nm. In this study, both NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+ and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+ UCNPs operating under 980 nm excitation were synthesized and their catalytic effect on the PEG-l-ASNase enzyme was evaluated. Fig. 3 A shows the XRD graph of the synthesized UCNPs. In the spectrum of particles coated with 5 % PEI by mass on their surfaces in situ, the peaks observed at 2θ=17.38, 30.48°, 30.88°, 34.19°, 40.06°, 43.75°, 50.35°, 54.65°, 62.64°, and 64.34° are hexagonal β-NaYF4 crystal, respectively. corresponding to the (100), (110), (011), (200), (111), (201), (300), (102), (112), and (220) planes of the phase (JCPDS No. 16–0334) [56]. No signal of any impurity was observed in the spectra, and Nd3+ ion contribution and PEI coating did not cause any change. The existence of the PEI coating is evidenced by the presence of NH in-plane bending vibrations at 1600 cm−1 and characteristic CN stretching vibrations at 1120–1050 cm−1 in the FTIR spectrum (Fig. 3B). Although the thermograms in Fig. 3C have similar characteristics for both particles, the differences in the initial temperatures of decomposition of organic groups are noteworthy. While the thermal decomposition onset temperature for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+ UCNPs was 225 °C, it was measured as 167 °C for NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+UCNPs. Mass losses between the temperatures at which thermal decomposition begins and 500 °C, where constant mass loss is reached for both particles, are 0.77 % for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs and 2.29 % for NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs, and are significantly different from each other. In the upconversion luminescence spectrum of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+ UCNPs synthesized by hydrothermal method and whose surfaces were coated with 5 % PEI by mass in situ (Fig. 3D), 407 nm (2H9/2→4I15/2), 520 nm (2H11/2→4I15/2), well-defined emission bands around 540 nm (4S3/2→4I15/2) and 654 nm (4F9/2→4I15/2) have been seen in the literature. As nanoparticle sizes increase, both green emission peak intensities around 540 nm and red emission peak intensities around 654 nm increase, and as the size decreases, the red light/green light intensity ratio increases [57]. As seen in Fig. 3D, the red-light emission intensity of the synthesized UCNPs is higher and this is due to the bigger particle size. From the TEM photographs given in Fig. 4 , the particles are rod-shaped, the width of NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI nanorods was < 200 nm, while the width of NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+ nanorods was <400 nm, and the sizes of UCNPs with Nd3+ contribution are different from each other. Appears to be higher compared to the zeta potentials of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+ and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+UCNPs were measured as 59.07 ± 0.42 mV and 51.5 ± 0.53 mV. Our basic approach in enzyme immobilization to the surface of UCNPs was to ensure the binding of PEGylated l-ASNase to the surface of UCNPs coated with PEI via van der Waals interactions. Both the NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI and NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs that we synthesized have a surface charge of >50 mV and the PEG-l-ASNase enzyme has a working pH of 7.4 in the biological environment. Since it is negatively charged, van der Waals interactions will easily occur between UCNP and the enzyme. Accordingly, the samples were re-characterized after enzyme loading at the optimum rate into UCNPs with both different wavelength excitations. From the XRD graphs, it was seen that enzyme loading did not cause any change in the crystal structure, as expected (Fig. 5 A). All planes of β-hexagonal geometry are seen in both UCNPs. UCNP-enzyme bindings were examined by FTIR spectrometry. In the FTIR spectrum of UCNPs given in Fig. 5B, stretching vibration peaks belonging to hydroxyl groups are seen at 3423 cm−1 and 1653 cm−1 after l-ASNase enzyme loading coated with PEG with many OH groups. The peaks seen around 2954, 2920 and 2847 cm−1 belong to the alkyl groups of the PEG polymer chain. The peaks arising from CH bending and CH stretching vibrations at 1380 and 1046 cm−1 and the CH twisting vibration at 1235 cm−1 prove the presence of PEGylated enzyme on UCNP surfaces [58]. Compared to the spectra of unloaded UCNPs in Fig. 3B, UCNP-enzyme FTIR spectra consist of signals related to the PEG polymer, which indicates that the particle surfaces are largely physically covered with the enzyme. PEG-LASNase loaded UCNPs were detected under NIR light excitation (980 nm NIR laser for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI and 808 nm NIR laser for NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI) at 520, 540, and 654 nm. It emits corresponding to the 2H11/2→4I15/2, 4S3/2→4I15/2 and 4F9/2→4I15/2 transitions, respectively, which shows that the FRET energy transfer mechanism is working (Fig. 5C). Schematic energy level diagram of the upconversion emission process for the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/55 PEI systems was displayed in Fig. 5D with the origin of various emissions from both Er3+ and Nd3+ ions. After NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs where the sensitizer is only Er3+ ions are adsorbed the excitation energy at 980 nm, an electron is excited directly from ground state of Er3+ ion to its 4 I11/2 state via energy transfer from Yb3+ ions undergoing 2F5/2→2F7/2. The electron can be further raised to 4F7/2 and 2H9/2 state in succession by similar energy transfer. At the same time, some electrons having comparatively higher energies occupy intermediates states and return to the excited states after releasing the excess amount as heat, i.e., lattice vibrations; the process commonly known as multi phonon relaxation. The radiative transitions from 2H9/2, 4S3/2, 2H11/2, and 4F9/2 to 4I15/2 produce upconversion emissions at wavelengths 410, 520, 540 and 654 nm, respectively. The 4F9/2 level may also be populated similarly by excitation from 4I13/2 state and subsequent relaxation of electrons via 2F9/2→4I15/2 transition leads to red emission at 654 nm [59]. In the presence of Nd3+ ions, an electron is first excited from the 4I9/2 to 4F5/2 state of the Nd3+ ions after absorbing the excitation energy at 808 nm, and then relaxed to the 4F3/2 level through multiphoton processes. The Nd3+ ions transfer their absorbed energy to Yb3+ ions and excite them from the 2F7/2 to the 2F5/2 state. The Nd3+ ions transfer their absorbed energy to Yb3+ ions and excite them from the 2F7/2 to the 2F5/2 state. The subsequent excitation and relaxation processes for NaYF4: Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs occur in the same way as for NaYF4: Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs [60]. From the TEM photographs given in Fig. 6 , it can be seen that after PEG-l-ASNase loading, the surfaces of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI UCNPs are densely covered and there are aggregations within the polymer structure. In NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI/PEG-l-ASNase particles, distortions in particle shapes due to aggregation are quite striking. 3.2 Adsorption isotherms and kinetic To understand the effect mechanism of NIR stimulation on enzyme activity, the adsorption and diffusion mechanism of the substrate was determined by Langmuir, Freundlich isotherms, and intra-particle diffusion models. The Langmuir model assumes that the adsorption is of the monolayer type and describes the adsorbent surface as homogeneous, that is, the surface areas are the same. The Freundlich isotherm explains multilayer adsorption and assumes that the adsorbent surface is heterogeneous. Fig. S1 shows the data of Langmuir, Freundlich isotherms and intra-particle diffusion model for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. The highest monolayer adsorption capacity obtained from the Langmuir isotherm was found to be 19.26 μg/mg. The value of 1/n was 0.91 (between 0 and 1) resulted in good sorption and this result indicates that sorption occurs in the same way throughout the entire process (L-type isotherm). However, the Langmuir isotherm (R2 = 0.968) fits the experimental better than the Freundlich isotherm (R2 = 0.949). In addition, the KL value (0.36 mL/mg) was in the range of 0.2–0.5. This clearly shows that the adsorption process was positive and irreversible [44]. Of the two isotherm models, the Langmuir model offered the best correlation factor and best fitting of the experimental data for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/PEI. These outcomes showed that the adsorption was mainly monolayer adsorption. Additionally, the intra-particle diffusion model was studied to determine the determining step of the adsorption rate. kintra represents the initial intra-particle diffusion rate and the C value represents the diffusion resistance. kintra and C values were found to be 31.46 μg/mg.min0.5 and 24.04, respectively. As can be seen from the graph, adsorption occurs in three different steps. The first step refers to the diffusion from the solution to the adsorbent boundary surface, the second step refers to the intraparticle diffusion from the outer surface to the pores, and the last step refers to the diffusion to the inner parts. The slope of the line for each region corresponds to the adsorption rate of that region. Intraparticle diffusion occurs faster for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/PEI-PEG-l-ASNase compared to other steps. Fig. S2 shows the data of Langmuir, Freundlich isotherms and intra-particle diffusion model for NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. According to the Langmuir isotherm, the monolayer adsorption capacity of the NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/PEI was found to be 7.41 μg/mg. Since the correlation value of the Langmuir isotherm (R2 = 0.9907) was higher than that of the Freundlich isotherm (R2 = 0.9683), the adsorption mechanism for NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/PEI-PEG-l-ASNase fits the Langmuir model. This shows that adsorption mainly occurs in a single layer. The 1/n value obtained from the Freundlich isotherm is higher than 1 (1.62), which generally indicates that the adsorption was suitable for the S-type isotherm. In addition, the KL value (0.24 mL/mg) was in the range of 0.2–0.5. This clearly shows that the adsorption process was positive and irreversible [44]. Although these types of isotherms are less common, they are observed in structures containing polar functional groups and at low concentrations. It refers to adsorption in which the adsorbate competes with water. In the intra-particle diffusion kinetic model, the kintra of the third region was found to be 78.68 μg/mg.dk0.5 and the C value was 237.67. The high correlation coefficient obtained (R2 = 0.999) shows that diffusion occurs much faster for the particle. 3.3 Biochemical characterization 3.3.1 Optimization of immobilization conditions Immobilization time is an important parameter affecting the activity of the immobilized enzyme. The effect of immobilization time on enzyme activity is shown in Fig. S3a. The immobilization time allows interaction between the enzyme and the carrier. However, further increase in inactivity time led to a decrease in enzyme activity. This decrease can be attributed to greater interaction between the support and the enzyme leading to the loss of active sites [25]. Ultimately, an immobilization time of 2 h was chosen for both NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. In Fig. S3b, it is evident that an enzyme concentration of 75 U represents the optimal parameter for both NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. As anticipated in both cases, enzyme activity demonstrated an increase with rising enzyme concentration. However, a slight decrease in enzyme loading was observed after reaching saturation. This decline in activity may be attributed to the concealment of certain active sites caused by the aggregation of a high enzyme concentration. Alternatively, it could be a consequence of the heightened enzyme concentration leading to the obstruction of mass transfer due to a congested space [25]. 3.3.2 IY and ae values Table 1 shows IY and AE values of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. The NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase had an IY of 89.6 ± 0.34 % and an AE of 85.69 ± 4.95 % whereas NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase had an IY of 98.17 ± 0.13 % and an AE of 86.78 ± 1.58 %. The achieved high IY and AE values can be attributed not solely to the substantial surface area of UCNPs but also to the effective modification of UCNPs with PEI. 3.3.3 Optimal temperature and pH The relative activity of PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase at different temperatures (20 – 70 ⁰C) is shown in Fig. 7 A. The results indicated that the optimal temperature for PEG-l-ASNase was 40 ⁰C, while the activity of the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was optimal at 45 ⁰C, and 50 ⁰C, respectively. Immobilized PEG-l-ASNases are more stable than their soluble counterparts because immobilization helps to improve the heat tolerance of the enzyme by making appropriate conformational changes [61]. As expected, the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase possessed better temperature stability than the PEG-l-ASNase. Surprisingly, it was found that the shift in optimum temperature increased by 10 °C when l-ASNase was immobilized on the NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. In addition, higher residues in enzyme activity were observed at increasing temperatures compared to the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. For instance, at the highest temperature (70 °C), the relative activity of PEG-l-ASNase, the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was 26.0 %, 56.0 %, and 59.8 %, respectively. Similar results regarding the influence of temperature were also observed in our previous studies [25,41,62]. The optimum pH of the PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was investigated in the pH range of 4.0–10.0, and the results are shown in Fig. 7B. The pH–activity profile revealed pH 8.5 as the optimal value of PEG-l-ASNase, while the optimum value for the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase shifted to 8.0. Similarly, previous studies show that the l-ASNase enzyme exhibits greater catalytic ability in an alkaline medium [15,26]. In addition, the higher relative activity and resistance of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was observed mainly for all pH values, while the relative activity of PEG-l-ASNase decreased sharply at the same pH values. While the variation of the optimal pH is associated with the charge characteristic of the carrier support [63], the high relative activity in the wide pH scale can be explained by the effect of the strong bond between the enzyme and the carrier support [61]. 3.3.4 Thermostability and pH stability The thermostability of the PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was analyzed for 6 h at 50 °C and was compared (Fig. 8 A). As can be seen from thermal curves, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase showed higher thermostability at 50 °C compared to the PEG-l-ASNase. After 1 h, the PEG-l-ASNase presented 58.68 %, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase showed 86.96 %, and 88.52 % residual activity, respectively. Moreover, the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase (59.32 %), and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase (62.39 %) displayed excellent thermostability after 6 h incubation at 50 °C. On the contrary, the PEG-l-ASNase lost 50 % of its activity within 3 h and exhibited only 28.94 % after 6 h. These observations demonstrated that UCNPs provide thermal protection at elevated temperatures. As can be seen from Fig. 8B, C, there was a faster decrease in the pH stability of PEG-l-ASNase at pH 4.0 and 9.0. In a similar manner to the explanation discussed above, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, in comparison to the PEG-l-ASNase, showed better stability and high activity both acidic and alkali pH values. This result was mainly attributed to immobilization helps in improving the pH tolerance of the enzyme by making suitable conformational changes, which was consistent with our previous report [64]. 3.3.5 Reusability and storage stability Reusability is one of the most significant advantages of immobilized enzymes on both an economic and industrial scale [65]. Twenty consecutive cycles of use were performed under the same conditions to evaluate the reusability test. As shown in Fig. 8D, the residual activity of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was reduced to 57.8 % and 56.7 %, respectively, after 20 repeated catalytic cycles. According to the results, they exhibited good operational stability and can be considered as a safe and useful matrix that can be used at the commercial level. Long-term storage stability is another parameter that provides cost-effective properties to immobilized enzymes. To investigate the long-term storage stability, the PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase were stored at 4 ⁰C and room temperature for 4 weeks (Fig. 9 A, B). After 4 weeks of storage at 4 ⁰C, the PEG-l-ASNase retained 52.64 % of its initial activity, whereas the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase retained 66.74 %, and 63.38, respectively. After 4 weeks of storage at room temperature, the PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase retained 24.90 %, 62.17 %, and 59.43 %, respectively, of their initial activity. These results revealed that the storage stability of the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases was notably better than that of the PEG form, and the UCNPs were found to be a sustainable and beneficial carrier matrix. 3.4 Kinetic parameters and activation energy After measuring the activities of these enzymes at different substrate concentrations, the Km and Vmax values of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase were calculated using Lineweaver-Burk plots and these values are summarized in Table 2 . In our previous study, PEG-l-ASNase had the apparent Km of 2.31 mM and the maximum reaction rate Vmax of 140.85 µmol/min [37]. The NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase had the apparent Km of 1.56 mM and 1.95 mM, respectively, and the maximum reaction rate Vmax of 138.89 µmol/min and 126.58 µmol/min, respectively. This obvious decrease in Km value demonstrated that the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases have an apparent higher affinity for its substrate than that of PEG-l-ASNase, which means the lid opening of the enzyme so that its active site becomes more accessible [66]. In addition, the increased affinity may be due to the protective effect of the UCNP structure, which enables enzymes to maintain conformational stability, providing a good microenvironment for enzymes. However, in some immobilization studies, it has been reported that the Km value of immobilized l-ASNase increases, indicating less enzyme affinity for the substrate [41,67]. This may be due to the formation of a more inflexible enzyme structure after immobilization, causing an increase in mass transfer limitation and therefore a decrease in enzyme affinity. In this study, the flexibility and active conformation of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase were preserved. Thus, Km values decreased even after immobilization. Interestingly, the Vmax value of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was almost not changed, while the Vmax value of NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase lower than that of PEG-l-ASNase. The decrease in the Vmax value might be associated with mass-transfer limitations and diffusional limitations. The changes in the kinetic parameters in the current investigation are consistent with previously reported results [26,68,69]. Another observation is that the Ea values were calculated from the slope of log% relative activity versus 1000/T (Fig. S4). The Ea values for the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase (10.97 kJ mol−1), and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase (11.00 kJ mol−1) were lower than for the PEG-l-ASNase (17.13 kJ mol−1). The decrease in Ea after immobilization is due to a decrease in the energy required to make the activated enzyme-substrate complex [70]. 3.5 Stability in serum and trypsin digestion The in vitro stability of the PEG-l-ASNase, NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase in blood serum was examined (Fig. 9C). When the samples were incubated in human serum for 7 days, while PEG-l-ASNase maintained 58.4 % of its initial activity, the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase maintained 76.2 %, and 82.8 % of their initial activity, respectively. These results indicated that the UCNPs protected PEG-l-ASNase with steric hindrance to the enzymatic hydrolysis caused by proteases in serum [71]. As shown in Fig. 9D, the resistance of PEG-l-ASNase against trypsin digestion was investigated. PEG-l-ASNase maintained only about 83 % of its initial activity after five minutes, whereas NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase retained more than 94 % of their initial activity. With increasing digestion time, the remaining activities of all samples went down gradually and NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase possessed about 30 % of the initial activities after incubating for 120 min, whereas PEG-l-ASNase nearly denaturized (only 14 % activity). These findings demonstrated that the resistance of UCNP@PEG-l-ASNase greatly improved when compared with that of PEG-l-ASNase. 3.6 Effects of metallic ions and organic solvents on enzyme activities The effects of various metallic ions and organic solvents on both PEG-l-ASNase and immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were systematically evaluated. As illustrated in Table S1, diverse inhibitory or activating effects were observed, dependent on the specific metal ion or solvent employed. Remarkably, immobilized PEG-l-ASNases demonstrated activation in the presence of Mg2+, Ca2+, Ni2+, and THF. This activation could be attributed to the stabilization of the active conformation, thereby enhancing enzyme activity. In summary, the findings suggest that immobilized PEG-l-ASNases exhibit superior stability and increased tolerance to various metal ions and organic solvents, highlighting their potential for enhanced enzymatic performance in diverse conditions. 3.7 Laser characterization experiments Laser power, irradiation time, and irradiation distance are the major adjustable parameters for an NIR system. The relative activity gradually increased with laser power. The curves obtained showed that NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase reached the maximum activity under NIR irradiation for 60 min at 800 mW at a distance of 1 cm (Fig. S5), while NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase reached the maximum activity under NIR irradiation for 120 min at 200 mW at a distance of 3 cm (Fig. S6). The impact of NIR power on PEG-l-ASNase activity was investigated, as depicted in Fig. S5A and S6A. The enzyme activities of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase exhibited a remarkable 1.8-fold increase at 800 mW and 3.2-fold at 200 mW under NIR irradiation compared to the control without laser exposure. As power escalated, the energy input in the reaction system increased, prompting the active conformation of PEG-l-ASNase and thereby enhancing enzyme activity [37,72]. However, a further elevation in NIR power resulted in a significant reduction in PEG-l-ASNase activity. Under extreme conditions, NIR irradiation could inflict substantial damage on polypeptide chains, leading to enzyme inactivation [37]. To determine the optimal distance for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, experiments were conducted at varying exposure distances (1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 cm), as illustrated in Fig. S5B and S6B. The graph indicates peak activity for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase at NIR exposure distances up to 1 and 3 cm, respectively. Optimal enzyme conformational changes occurred when exposed to NIR within these distances, resulting in increased enzyme activity. In addition to power intensity and distance, exposure time of irradiation is a critical parameter. The impact of exposure time on the activity of both NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was studied from 5 to 120 min. Fig. S5C and S6C illustrates the influence of exposure time on PEG-l-ASNase activity. Results showed that maximum enzyme activity for NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase was achieved at NIR exposure times of 60 and 120 min, respectively. Extended exposure to NIR, however, decreased PEG-l-ASNase activity compared to untreated PEG-l-ASNase. Control experiments with PEG-l-ASNase showed no significant increase in activity after NIR irradiation (data not shown). Overall, these findings underscore that PEG-l-ASNase enzyme activity can be selectively modulated by NIR light under optimized conditions. 3.8 Cell viability The potential cytotoxicity of NPs is a very important indicator in biomedical applications. Therefore, the in vitro cytotoxicity of the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI with and without PEG-l-ASNase was tested in mouse fibroblast (L-929) cells using the MTT assay after 24, 48, and 72 h of treatment. As shown in Fig. 10 , all samples at different concentrations (12.5–200 μg/mL) were confirmed to be biocompatible. These findings are consistently in line with previous studies [73,74] and confirm the non-cytotoxic nature of the studied NPs. This robust biocompatibility underscores their potential suitability for a variety of biomedical applications. 3.9 Hemolysis assay As seen from Fig. S7, negligible hemolysis was observed at concentrations for all samples tested. Besides, the photographs showing the hemolysis experiment are given in Fig. S7A, B. Whereas the red color of the released hemoglobin from damaged cells is clearly observable for positive control (deionized water), the supernatants of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase were almost colorless at all concentrations. According to our data, in the concentration range of 12.5–200 µg/mL, the hemolytic activity of NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase, and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase against erythrocytes was measured as less than 5 %, which indicates low hemolytic activity and is a suitable biocompatibility indicator for in vivo applications [75]. 3.10 Determination of inhibition on cancer cells The NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase displayed generally higher performance at tested conditions as compared to the NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase. Based on these studies, we selected NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase for in vitro antitumor efficiency experiments. Additionally, PEG-l-ASNase and NIR groups were used as controls to eliminate any interference effects. The antiproliferative effects of the tested groups on cancer cell lines were assessed using the MTT assay specifically conducted on HL-60 cell lines. The obtained results are visually presented in Fig. 11 . The proliferation inhibition values of the tested groups were obviously different. While PEG-l-ASNase and NIR groups inhibited HL-60 cancer cells by 13.70 % and 7.62 %, respectively. On the other hand, NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase+NIR groups caused inhibition by 12.23 % and 29.33 %, respectively. These results revealed that the activity of the adsorbed PEG-l-ASNase was also increased more than 2-fold under NIR irradiation compared to its non-NIR counterpart in the in vitro system. Based on this, herein, we proposed both a nanoplatform to ensure the stability and recycling of enzymes and a synergistic strategy to enhance the activity of the enzyme. 4 Conclusion In summary, enzyme immobilization is a very robust strategy, however, being not successful in maintaining the high catalytic activity of enzymes immobilized by different methods. Herein, we present for the first time a simple and promising technique to demonstrate both the use of UCNPs as supports and the induction of enzyme activity immobilized in the same particles. Using PEG-l-ASNase, an important enzyme in the treatment of leukemia, as a model enzyme, this study demonstrated outstanding immobilization performance, exhibiting significantly improved stability under various conditions. For this purpose, UCNPs (NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI) were synthesized by hydrothermal method and well characterized via different techniques. Under optimal conditions, PEG-l-ASNase was immobilized on NaYF4:Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI and NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI with 89.6 ± 0.34 % and 98.17 ± 0.13 % of IY and 85.69 ± 4.95 % and 86.78 ± 1.58 % of AE, respectively. The MTT assay testing confirmed that UCNPs with and without enzyme were biocompatible for l-929 cells. The obtained results revealed that compared to the PEG-l-ASNase, the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases increased reusability as well as improved pH, thermal, storage stability, and trypsin resistance. The enhanced enzyme stability can be attributed to the interactions formed between the PEG-l-ASNase and the UCNPs. Moreover, it is worth noting that Km values decreased for both immobilized PEG-l-ASNases, suggesting that the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate increased after immobilization. Lastly, NaYF4:Nd3+, Yb3+, Er3+/5 % PEI-PEG-l-ASNase induced under optimal NIR conditions exhibited an antitumor activity of approximately 2.4-fold compared to the no-NIR control when applied to human leukemia cells (HL-60). Taken together, NIR-inducible UCNPs may be a promising support for the immobilization of various enzymes in biomedical and industrial applications. Further studies on the induction of different enzymes by NIR are in progress. coredata.dc:description: Immobilized enzymes have encountered two main challenges: Reduced enzyme activity compared to free enzymes and exhausted immobilized enzymes due to reusability. Herein, we suggested a promising activity enhancement strategy to overcome these challenges. The emission from upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) under near-infrared (NIR) excitation can increase the activity of PEG-l-ASNase due to Förster Resonance Energy Transfer. For this purpose, UCNPs were initially synthesized using the hydrothermal method. Subsequently, these UCNPs were functionalized with a polycationic polymer, branched polyethyleneimine (PEI), and the immobilization of PEG-l-ASNase was achieved through adsorption. We preliminarily explored the parameters such as enzyme concentration, incubation time, pH, temperature, reusability, storage stability, and kinetic study, etc. Further, the in vitro biocompatibility, hemolytic behavior, and anticancer activity of the produced UCNPs were also analyzed as crucial parameters. The results showed the pH durance, thermal and storage stability of the immobilized PEG-l-ASNases were enhanced. The immobilized PEG-l-ASNases maintained their activity to ≥55 % after 20 cycles. Enzyme immobilization led to a decrease in Km and Vmax compared to PEG-l-ASNase. In vitro assays revealed that immobilized enzyme further reduced the proliferation of human leukemia cell line (HL-60) upon NIR irradiation exposure but did not cause toxicity. This research may provide a new strategy to promote the catalytic activity of l-ASNase and demonstrates its potential application on human leukemia cells. Finally, these outcomes are valuable for the use of NIR induction in enzymatic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Near-infrared inducible supports in bio-catalysts design: A useful and versatile tool in enhancement of enzyme activity
